lung cancer.text: Lung cancer comprises mainly non–small cell (≈80–85%) and small cell subtypes (~15%), which differ in staging and therapy approaches.
Key risk factors: tobacco smoking, secondhand smoke, radon, occupational exposures (e.g., asbestos), and air pollution.
Diagnosis uses chest CT, biopsy for histology, and staging (TNM for NSCLC; limited vs. extensive for SCLC).
Treatments vary by stage and subtype: surgery, radiation, chemo, targeted (EGFR/ALK/ROS1/BRAF/MET/KRAS G12C) and immunotherapy (PD-1/PD-L1).
Low-dose CT screening is recommended for certain high-risk adults; supportive care includes smoking cessation and symptom control.

chronic kidney disease.text: CKD is persistent kidney damage or eGFR <60 for ≥3 months; diabetes and hypertension are common causes.
Management includes BP and glucose control, ACEi/ARB, SGLT2 inhibitors, and nephrology referral by risk.
Lifestyle measures and vaccinations reduce complications.

hypertension.text: Hypertension is persistently elevated BP confirmed with repeated or ambulatory monitoring.
First-line drugs often include thiazide-like diuretics, ACEi/ARB, or CCBs; lifestyle change is foundational.

diabetes.text: Type 1 involves autoimmune β-cell loss; Type 2 involves insulin resistance with relative deficiency.
Management: lifestyle, metformin first-line for T2D, + GLP-1 RAs / SGLT2 inhibitors / insulin per comorbidities and A1c.
Screen for complications: eyes, kidneys, feet; manage BP/lipids; personalize targets.
